comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: Whose soldiers are they sewing for?

comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content:
I bet the women in fancy hats and dressed in black are there to show support for the 'common' women who are doing all the work.  

Not sure I worded that right but it does seem like an odd picture to me.  I also wonder where that particular Berlin is.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: The New York Times on December 17, 1914, reports but one story of many of relief work efforts carried out on both sides of the Atlantic. "A hearty reception awaits the American Christmas expedition which will reach Berlin tomorrow from the Christmas ship Jason. "The American Kitchen will make gifts to 200 women and 200 children, ... fifty babies are being cared for in the Infants' Home, while other organizations of American women have been busily engaged in sewing for the past two months, preparing gifts for children." The complete NY Times article can be read here. As for "which Berlin" ... it was Germany.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The Bain collection has 9 photos of the Christmas Ship Jason and the preparation of gifts for shipment to war orphans of the fighting countries. www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/tags/christmass...
